content.p: The average GFR is 125 milliliters (4 ounces) per minute, which adds up to nearly 140 liters (50 gallons) a day.

question.body: What are the consequences of a GFR that is too high?

multiple_choice.choice: Waste products will accumulate in the renal tubules, ultimately leading to illness and death if untreated.
Needed substances will rush through the renal tubules ultimately leading to illness and death if untreated.
Needed substances will rush through the renal tubules and lost in urine.

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is not what happens of GFR is too high.
Incorrect. There will be a consequence.
Incorrect. Incorrect. A high GFR can be the result of high blood pressure not a low blood pressure.
Correct. If the GFR is too high, needed substances will rush through the renal tubules too quickly to be completely absorbed, and they will be lost in urine.

question.body: What are the consequences of a GFR that is too low?

multiple_choice.choice: Waste products will accumulate in the plasma, ultimately leading to illness and death if untreated.
Needed substances will rush through the renal tubules ultimately leading to illness and death if untreated.
Un-needed substances will stay in the renal tubules.

response.feedback: Correct. A GFR that is too low will allow waste products to accumulate in the plasma, ultimately leading to illness and death if not corrected.
Incorrect. There will be a consequence.
Incorrect. This is a made up consequence that combines the results of GFR that is too high and too low.

Incorrect. If the GFR is too high, unneeded substances will not stay in the renal tubules. Rather, needed substances will rush through the renal tubules too quickly to be completely absorbed, and they will be lost in urine.
